margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∗</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> then <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><msub><mo>≡</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{\phi(n)} \equiv_{n} 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.038em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.888em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">ϕ</span><span class="mopen mtight">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span><span class="mclose mtight">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel"><span class="mrel">≡</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.151392em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span></em></p>
<p><strong>Example</strong><br>
<em>Using the formula for <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\phi(n),</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ϕ</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> we can see that <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>15</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>⋅</mo><mn>5</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>8.</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\phi(15)=\phi(3 \cdot 5)=(3-1)(5-1)=8 .</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ϕ</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ϕ</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">8.</span></span></span></span></span> Euler’s theorem says that raising any element of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="double-struck">Z</mi><mn>15</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∗</mo></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbb{Z}_{15}^{*}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.936998em; vertical-align: -0.248108em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.688696em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.45189em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">15</span></span></span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∗</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.248108em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> to the 8 power results in 1: We can use Sage to verify this:</em></p>
<blockquote>
<p>sage: for i in range(15):<br>
<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>…</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mo>:</mo><mspace width="1em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ldots.:\quad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="minner">…</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span></span></span></span></span>if gcd(i, 15) == 1:<br>
<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>…</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mo>:</mo><mspace width="2em"></mspace><mspace width="1em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ldots.: \qquad\quad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="minner">…</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span></span></span></span></span> print ("%d^8 mod 15 = %d" % (i, i ^8 % 15))<br>
1^ 8 mod 15 = 1<br>
2^ 8 mod 15 = 1<br>
4^ 8 mod 15 = 1<br>
7^ 8 mod 15 = 1<br>
8^ 8 mod 15 = 1<br>
11^ 8 mod 15 = 1<br>
13^ 8 mod 15 = 1<br>
14^ 8 mod 15 = 1</p>
</blockquote>
<h2 id="the-rsa-function">13.2 The RSA Function</h2>
<p>The RSA function is defined as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Let <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">p</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">p</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">q</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">q</span></span></span></span></span> be distinct primes (later we will say more about how they are chosen), and let <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>p</mi><mi>q</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N=p q . N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.87777em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">pq</span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> is called the <strong>RSA modulus</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Let <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> be integers such that <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi><msub><mo>≡</mo><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e d \equiv _{\phi(N)}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.04964em; vertical-align: -0.3552em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel"><span class="mrel">≡</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3448em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.5198em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">ϕ</span><span class="mopen mtight">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose mtight">)</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3552em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. That is, <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> are multiplicative inverses mod <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>−</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\phi(N)-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ϕ</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">−</span></span></span></span></span> not <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow> <mo lspace="0.22em" rspace="0.22em"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi></mrow></mo> <mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">!</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\bmod\ N !</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.0555556em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mod</span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.0555556em;"></span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose">!</span></span></span></span></span></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The RSA function is: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>↦</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi>N</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x \mapsto x^{e} \% N,</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↦</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94444em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> where <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="double-struck">Z</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x \in \mathbb{Z}_{N}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83889em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.328331em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The inverse RSA function is: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>↦</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mi>d</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi>N</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">y \mapsto y^{d} \% N,</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.70544em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↦</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.04355em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.849108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> where <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="double-struck">Z</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x \in \mathbb{Z}_{N}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83889em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.328331em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Essentially, the RSA function (and its inverse) is a simple modular exponentiation. <p>Let’s make sure the function we called the “inverse RSA function” is actually an inverse of the RSA function. Let’s start with an example:</p>
<p><strong>Example</strong><br>

<p><em>Then we can compute the exponentse and d. vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">p</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">∗</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">q</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <p><em>We can now raise something to the e power and again to the d power:</em></p>

sage: y<br>
<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1798996</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1798996</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1798996</span></span></span></span></span><br>

<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>31415926</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">31415926</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">31415926</span></span></span></span></span></p>
</blockquote>
<p><em>As you can see, raising to the e power and then d power <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>d</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(mod\ N)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord mathnormal">o</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> seems to bring us back to where we started <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(x) .</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span></em></p>
<p>We can argue that raising-to-the-<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; <span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mi>t</mi></msup><mi>x</mi><msub><mo>≡</mo><mi>N</mi></msub><msup><mn>1</mn><mi>t</mi></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">

<h3 id="how-not-to-exponentiate-huge-numbers">How [Not] to Exponentiate Huge Numbers</h3>
<p>When you see an expression like " <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><msup><mi>N</mi><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{e} \% N^{\prime \prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.807452em; vertical-align: -0.05556em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.751892em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, you might be tempted to implement it with the following algorithm:</p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><menclose notation="top bottom left right"><mtable rowspacing="0.1600em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><munder accentunder="true"><mrow><mtext>NAIVEEXPONENTIATE</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>e</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>:</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="true">‾</mo></munder></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mtext>result</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mrow><mtext>for&nbsp;</mtext><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mstyle><mtext>&nbsp;to&nbsp;</mtext><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mi>e</mi></mstyle><mtext>:&nbsp;//&nbsp;compute&nbsp;</mtext><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup></mstyle></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace><mtext>result&nbsp;=&nbsp;result</mtext><mo>×</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mtext>return&nbsp;result&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></menclose></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{|l|}\hline
\underline{\text{NAIVEEXPONENTIATE} (x, e, N):} \\
\quad\text{result} =1 \\
\quad \text{for $i=1$ to $e$: // compute $x^{e}$} \\
\qquad \text{result = result} \times x \\
\text{return result}\ \%  N\\\hline
\end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 6.13em; vertical-align: -2.795em;"></span><span mathnormal">x</span></span></span><span class="" style="top: -0.565em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">return&nbsp;result</span></span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 2.795em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="vertical-separator" style="height: 6.09em; border-right-width: 0.04em; border-right-style: solid; margin: 0px -0.02em; vertical-align: -2.795em;"></span></span></span><span class="" style="top: -2.5em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 5.295em;"></span><span class="hline" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span class="" style="top: -8.59em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 5.295em;"></span><span class="hline" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 2.795em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>While this algorithm would indeed give the correct answer, it is a really bad way of doing it. In practice, we use RSA with numbers that are thousands of bits long. Suppose we run the NAIVEEXPONENTIATE algorithm with arguments <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>e</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x, e,</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> which are around a thousand bits each (so the magnitude of these numbers is close to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>1000</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{1000}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1000</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ):</p>
<ol>
<li>The algorithm will spend approximately <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>1000</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{1000}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1000</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> iterations in the for-loop!</li>
<li>The algorithm computes <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{e}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.664392em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> as an <em>integer</em> first, and then reduces that integer mod <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span>. Observe that <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is roughly 2000 bits long, <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is roughly 3000 bits long, etc. So it would take about <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>1000</mn></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mn>1000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{1000} \cdot 1000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1000</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span></span></span></span></span> bits just to write down the integer <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{e}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.664392em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<p>As you can see, there is neither enough time nor storage capacity in the universe to use this algorithm. So how can we actually compute values like <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{e} \% N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.80556em; vertical-align: -0.05556em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> on huge numbers?</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Suppose you were given an integer <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span></span> and were asked to compute <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>17</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{17}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">17</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. You can compute it as:<br>
<span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>17</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><munder><munder><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mo>⋯</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="true">undefined</mo></munder><mrow><mn>16</mn><mtext>&nbsp;multiplications&nbsp;</mtext></mrow></munder></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
x^{17}=\underbrace{x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot \cdots x}_{16 \text { multiplications }}
</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.864108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.864108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">17</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.91467em; vertical-align: -1.47022em;"></span><span class="mord munder"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.44445em;"><span class="" style="top: -1.66589em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">16</span><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">&nbsp;multiplications&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord munder"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.44445em;"><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.352em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="stretchy" style="height: 0.548em; min-width: 1.6em;"><span class="brace-left" style="height: 0.548em;"><svg width="400em" height="0.548em" viewBox="0 0 400000 548" preserveAspectRatio="xMinYMin slice"><path d="M0 6l6-6h17c12.688 0 19.313.3 20 1 4 4 7.313 8.3 10 13

-331-161C60.687 138.7 32.312 99.3 7 54L0 41V6z"></path></svg></span><span class="brace-center" style="height: 0.548em;"><svg width="400em" height="0.548em" viewBox="0 0 400000 548" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMin slice"><path d="M199572 214

But a more clever way is to observe that:<br>
<span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>17</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>16</mn></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
x^{17}=x^{16} \cdot x=\left(\left(\left(x^{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{2} \cdot x
</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.864108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.864108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">17</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.864108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.864108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">16</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: -0.95003em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size3">(</span></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size2">(</span></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.864108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size2">)</span></span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.35401em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.6029em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span></span></span><br>
This expression can be evaluated with only 5 multiplications (squaring is just muliplying a number by itself).</p>
<p>More generally, you can compute an expression like <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{e}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.664392em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> by following the recurrence below. The method is called <strong>exponentiation by repeated squaring,</strong> for reasons that are hopefully clear:</p>

<p>BETTEREXP divides the <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span></span></span></span></span> argument by two (more or less) each time it recurses, until reaching the base case. Hence, the number of recursive calls is <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">O(\log e) .</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> In each recursive call there are only a constant number of multiplications (including squarings). So overall this algorithm requires only <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">O(\log e)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <p>This algorithm avoids the problem of computing the astronomically huge integer <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x^{e} .</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.664392em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> It never needs to store any value (much) larger than <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p><strong>Warning:</strong> <em>Even this MopExp algorithm isn’t an ideal way to implement exponentiation for cryptographic purposes. Exercise 13.10 explores some unfortunate properties of this exponentiation algorithm.</em></p>
<p><strong>Example</strong><br>
<em>Most math libraries implement exponentiation using repeated squaring. For example, you can use Sage to easily calculate numbers with huge exponents:</em></p>
<blockquote>
<p>sage: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>42</mn><msup><mn>7</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mn>31415926</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">427^{\wedge} 31415926</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.751892em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">42</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.751892em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">31415926</span></span></span></span></span> % 100<br>
89</p>
</blockquote>
<p><em>However, this expression still tells Sage to compute <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>42</mn><msup><mn>7</mn><mn>31415926</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">427^{31415926}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">42</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">31415926</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> <strong>as an integer</strong>, before reducing it mod <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100.</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100 .</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">100.</span></span></span></span></span> As such, it takes some time to perform this computation.</em></p>
<p><em>If you try an expression like <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="monospace">x</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="monospace">e</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathtt{x}^{\wedge} \mathtt{e}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.751892em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathtt">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.751892em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathtt">e</span></span></span></span></span> %  <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="monospace">N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathtt{N}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.61111em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathtt">N</span></span></span></span></span> with a larger exponent, Sage will give a memory error. How can we tell Sage to perform modular reduction at every intermediate step during repeated squaring? The answer is to use Sage’s Mod objects, for example:</em></p>
<blockquote>
<p>sage: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Mod</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>427</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>100</mn><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mn>314159265358979</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\operatorname{Mod}(427,100)^{\wedge} 314159265358979</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.00189em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop"><span class="mord mathrm">Mod</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">427</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.751892em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">314159265358979</span></span></span></span></span><br>
63</p>
</blockquote>
<p><em>This expression performs repeated squaring on the object Mod <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>427</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>100</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(427,100) .</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">427</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> Since a Mod-object’s operations are all overloaded (to give the answer only mod <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span> ), this has the result of doing a modular reduction after every squaring and multiplication. This expression runs instantaneously, even with very large numbers.</em></p>
<h3 id="security-properties--discussion">Security Properties &amp; Discussion</h3>
<p>RSA is what is called a <strong>trapdoor function</strong>.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>One user generates the RSA parameters (primarily <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>e</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N, e,</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.87777em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> ) and makes <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span></span></span></span></span> public, while keeping <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> private.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Functionality properties: Given only the public information <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e,</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> it is easy to compute the RSA function <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>↦</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>e</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi>N</mi><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(x \mapsto x^{e} \% N\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↦</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.664392em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>. Given the private information <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(d)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> it clearly easy to compute the RSA inverse <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>↦</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mi>d</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi>N</mi><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(y \mapsto y^{d} \% N\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.20001em; vertical-align: -0.35001em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↦</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.849108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Security property</strong>: Given only the public information, it should be hard to compute the RSA inverse <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>↦</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mi>d</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi>N</mi><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(y \mapsto y^{d} \% N\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.20001em; vertical-align: -0.35001em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↦</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.849108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span> on randomly chosen values. In other words, the only person who is able to compute the RSA inverse function is the person who generated the RSA parameters.</p>
<p><strong>to-do</strong></p>
<blockquote>
<p><em>The security property is not natural to express in our language of security definitions (libraries).</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>Currently the best known attacks against RSA (<em>i.e.</em>, ways to compute the inverse RSA function given only the public information) involve factoring the modulus. If we want to ensure that RSA is secure as a trapdoor function, we must understand the state of the art for factoring large numbers.</p>
<p>Before discussing the performance of factoring algorithms, remember that we measure performance as a function of the <strong>length</strong> of the input - how many bits it takes to write the input. In a factoring algorithm, the input is a large number <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N,</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.87777em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> and it takes roughly <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n=\log _{2} N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.93858em; vertical-align: -0.24414em;"></span><span class="mop"><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.206968em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.45586em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.24414em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> bits to write down that number. We will discuss the running time of algorithms as a function of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n,</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span> not <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span>. Just keep in mind the difference in cost between <em>writing down</em> a 1000-bit number <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1000</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(n=1000)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em;
